fields.description: The Happiest City In America, According To Twitter, Is...
fields.author: Allison Stadd
fields.title: The Happiest City In America, According To Twitter, Is...

fields.description: Times Square isnt just the crossroads of the world  its the happiest spot in the Big Apple.The flashy strip and its surrounding streets  along with Midtown in general...
fields.author: KAYLEE OSOWSKI and NATALIE O’NEILL
fields.title: Times Square is NYC's happiest spot

fields.description: Hawaii was found to be the United States' happiest state in a recent study of geotagged tweets. The saddest? Louisiana.
fields.author: Heather Kelly
fields.title: The happiest and saddest states according to Twitter

fields.description: Napa and Vallejo received shout-outs this week for very different reasons.Once again, Vallejo was included in the Forbes magazine list of America''s most miserable cities. This year, ranking at No. 6. Meanwhile, a study also released this week found Napa to be the happiest city based on 10 million posts collected on the social media website Twitter.com. This was not the first time Vallejo has been included in the magazine''s lists.
fields.author: Irma Widjojo
fields.title: Happiest Cities, Most Miserable Cities Lists Reveal Disparity In Bay Area

fields.description: Tweets from 10 million users revealed that Napa is the happiest city, while Beaumont, Texas is the least happy
fields.author: Tia Ghose
fields.title: The List: The Happiest US Cities Based on Tweets

fields.description: The happiest city in America is Napa, California -- and the saddest all swear too much.
fields.author: Alex Madrigal
fields.title: The Geography of Happiness According to 10 Million Tweets

fields.description: The city where Ohio Gov. John Kasich will give his State of the State address Tuesday night is apparently one of the saddest in the nation.
fields.author: Mike Waterhouse
fields.title: City where Ohio Gov. John Kasich will give State of the State - Lima - named among nation's saddest

fields.description: Better think twice about that next tweet. It could be used to determine how happy you are
fields.author: Courtney Subramanian
fields.title: New Study Uses Tweets To Rank America`s Happiest Cities, States

fields.description: A new study tells you how happy your state is. But is it something a computer can really measure?
fields.author: Dan Stone
fields.title: Can a Computer Measure Your Happiness?

fields.description: Back in 2009, a group of University of Vermont researchers published a surprising paper in the Journal of Happiness Studies. In it, they outlined the process of determining the saddest day in recent memory, the day Michael Jackson died using data culled from blogs. The happiest, they found, was November 4, 2008--the day Obama was elected. The paper's underlying concept dates back to 1881, when an Irish scientist conceived of an instrument called a  "hedonometer" that could measure the happiness of a population.
fields.author: Kelsey Campbell-Dollaghan
fields.title: Mapping Happiness In American Cities, Using Twitter

fields.description: Breaking news: People drinking wine and hanging out on beaches are pretty happy. How do we know this? Twitter, of course! The Vermont Complex Systems Center, using Twitter and a fair amount of common sense, analyzed about 10 million geotagged tweets to find the happiest and least happy cities in the country.
fields.author: AJ Willingham
fields.title: Wine and rainbows! The happiest cities on Twitter

fields.description: A couple thousand tweets about Battle Creek couldn't be wrong, could they? Well, maybe. Someone's going to check on that and get back to you.
fields.author: Andy Fitzpatrick
fields.title: Battle Creek tweets a sad story

fields.description: I never thought I'd see the day when statistics about happiness were gathered from a social networking Web site, but I guess I should have expected it!
fields.author: Drew
fields.title: Twitter Ranks Fort Collins 13th Happiest City in the US

fields.description: If Twitter users are any indication, San Clemente is the third happiest city in America. That's according to an analysis of 10 million tweets in an article that appears in The Atlantic.
fields.author: FRED SWEGLES
fields.title: Tweet this: San Clemente third 'happiest' city in USA?

fields.description: Louisiana residents probably won't be too pleased to hear the following news, which, for them, won't really be a change of pace at all. According to a team at the very not-real-sounding Vermont Complex Systems Center and based on what is surely a totally objective and not-at-all arbitrary analysis...
fields.author: ASHLEY FEINBERG
fields.title: The Happiest and Saddest Places in the Country as Told by Your Tweets

fields.description: Disneyland proclaims itself the happiest place on Earth. But a team of statisticians places the nation’s crown of bliss instead on Napa — according to millions of Americans casting their votes 140 characters at a time.
fields.author: Howard Yune
fields.title: Napa: Twitter's happy town USA

fields.description: A new study suggests Houma-Thibodaux has some of the unhappiest people in the country among those on Twitter, anyway.
fields.author: Chance Ryan
fields.title: Area ranks low among country's happiest cities

fields.description: LONGMONT -- How happy are you, Longmont? Really happy, according to a Feb. 15 report from the University of Vermont Complex Systems Center.
fields.author: Magdalena Wegrzyn
fields.title: Tweet this: Longmont is second-happiest city

fields.description: Looking at 10 million tweets posted from 373 different sites across the country, the team ranked the saddest and happiest states and cities based on the frequency of happy and sad words posted onto the social networking site.
fields.author: JAMES NYE
fields.title: Study of 10 million tweets reveals Hawaii is the happiest state (no surprises there) while Louisiana is the saddest

fields.author: APARNA NATHAN
fields.title: The Science in Social Media: New Research Links Virtual and Psychological Worlds

fields.description: If you live in Hawaii, congratulations: according to a new study by researchers at the University of Vermont, you live in the happiest state in the union—at least as far as Twitter sentiment is concerned. (Hat tip to The Atlantic for posting about the research.)
fields.author: Nick Kolakowski
fields.title: Twitter Says Hawaii the Happiest State

fields.description: Los Angeles might not have made this list of happy cities, but three Southern California towns did. (Are...
fields.author: Dennis Romero
fields.title: California Dominates America's Happiest Twitter Cities
fields.imagelink: http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/assets_c/2013/02/san clemente girl Loco Steve Flickr comm ok-thumb-210x183.jpg

fields.description: The beach town scores very well in a University of Vermont analysis of Twitter.
fields.author: OC Patch
fields.title: San Clemente Among Top 10 Happiest Cities, Study Says

fields.description: Happiness levels captured by Tweets rise logarithmically with distance from our average location, say computer scientists studying Twitter sentiment.
fields.author: Physics arXiv Blog
fields.title: Twitter Happiness Levels Soar As People Travel Further From Home

fields.description: Happiness levels captured by Tweets rise logarithmically with distance from our average location, say computer scientists studying Twitter sentiment.
fields.author: Physics arXiv Blog
fields.title: Twitter Happiness Soars as People Travel Further From Home

fields.description: Researchers uncover the benefits of going somewhere different,Social Networking ,Twitter
fields.author: N/A
fields.title: Twitter messages reveal we're happier away from home

fields.description: Study: Twitter users hate being home (or at least are way happier being away). You know what''s horrible? Being at home. At least that is the general sentiment among Twitter users, whose level of happiness was shown to increase exponentially when they were far away from home.
fields.author: Evan Dashevsky
fields.title: Study: Twitter users hate being home (or at least are way happier being away)

fields.description: A new study shows levels of contentment encapsulated in Tweets are influenced by how far away from home you are.
fields.author: Maxine Wally
fields.title: Tweeting While Traveling Leads to a Happier Person

fields.description: More positives, fewer negatives. Complex.com: The original buyer's guide for men.
fields.author: Jill Krasny
fields.title: Study: Travel Makes Tweeters Seem Happier

fields.description: Tweets written away from home are far less likely to contain profanity and more likely to include terms like
fields.author: Evan Dashevsk
fields.title: Study: Twitter users hate being home (or at least are way happier being away)

fields.description: Twitter happiness could be found the further we get from home, a new study has suggested. Researchers at the University of Vermont found that Twitter users used more positive language in their tweets the further they got from home. The study terms the feelings expressed on Twitter as "Twitter sentiment.
fields.author: Alexander Besant
fields.title: Happiness is found far from home, Twitter study finds

fields.description: (Phys.org) A new mathematical analysis of Twitter messages has shown that happiness indicators increase logarithmically with distance from home, and that people who move around more are likely to be happier than those who stay close to home.
fields.author: Lin Edwards
fields.title: Math pattern analysis shows Twitter users happier the farther they are from home

fields.description: Research based on Twitter finds a connection between where you are and how happy you are.
fields.author: Kate Knibbs
fields.title: According to Twitter, happiness may be a plane ride away

fields.description: Computer scientists tracking millions of geolocated tweets have found that users express happiness more frequently the further they travel from home, and the larger their regular radius of movement.
fields.author: Liat Clark
fields.title: Study: geotagged tweets show we're happiest further from home

fields.description: Who doesn''t love packing up and heading out for a vacation? I''d think that pretty much all of us. But, with technology at our fingertips 24/7.
fields.author: Albert Costill
fields.title: Study Shows That Tweeters are Happier When They Travel

fields.description: Proving that a far-flung vacation or mini-holiday might just be the best way to lift your mood, a group of researchers found that people expressed more happiness in their tweets as they travelled farther away from their home.
fields.author: Marlene Leung
fields.title: The farther you travel from home, the happier your tweets: study

fields.description: As a long-time laborer in the vineyards of the dismal science, I was pleased recently when someone introduced me as "an optimistic economist." Perhaps in an effort to cement that moniker, and to escape the avalanche of "worst in the nation" tax and regulatory ratings, I was drawn to a report that pronounced Maine the second happiest state in the nation. "Is there something new here?" I wondered. "Or are we just a people who like high taxes and lots of regulation?
fields.author: Charles Lawton
fields.title: Tweetness should be taken with grain of salt

fields.description: People's tweets get significantly more positive in mood the greater the distance they are from home.
fields.author: Philip Ball
fields.title: Twitter study: Happiness rises the further you travel

fields.description: Foursquare introduced an updated version of its iPhone app last night that emphasizes discovery and learns what you like in order to make better recommendations about what you should do next.
fields.author: ANYA KAMENETZ
fields.title: How Foursquare Could Tell You Where To Find Happiness

fields.description: Despite mistakes over the Boston bombers, social media can help to find people quickly.
fields.author: Philip Ball
fields.title: Crowdsourcing in manhunts can work : Nature News

fields.description: A new study looks at the relationship between distance away from home and the language we use to describe it.
fields.author: Astrid Van Den Broek
fields.title: How Twitter can track your happiness

fields.description: People who hang out downtown get around, study finds.
fields.author: Stephanie Pappas
fields.title: Pretty City Images Reveal How People Move

fields.description: N/A
fields.author: Joshua Brown
fields.title: Happiness: There's an app for that

fields.description: Scientists have a pretty good idea about when people are happiest. Just check out the spikes that occur every Christmas on this happiness graph. But in a recent study, researchers sought to find out where people are happiest. And they used Twitter to do it.
fields.author: Breanna Draxler
fields.title: We're Happier When We're Farther From Home, Twitter Patterns Show

fields.author: The Asahi Shimbun Company
fields.title: Unsure?

fields.description: N/A
fields.author: Andrew Sullivan
fields.title: The Radius Of Bliss.

fields.description: A new data collection tool is being heralded as the first `mood ring'' of the social media world.
fields.author: Virginia Prescott
fields.title: The Hedonometer: A Mood Ring For Twitter

fields.description: The day of the Boston bombings was the world’s saddest in five years—at least according to the “Hedonometer,” a tool designed by mathematicians at the University of Vermont that acts like a mood ring for the Internet.
fields.author: Caitlin Dewey
fields.title: Measuring happiness through Twitter

fields.description: It's been defined by everyone from Plato to The Beatles. It's mentioned in the Declaration of Independence. Most of us are in search of it.  Now two professors are tracking your happiness.
fields.author: Devin Karambelas
fields.title: New technology developing a thermometer for happiness

fields.description: Can Twitter give us a sense of American sentiment? Can a review of millions of tweets reveal the saddest and happiest places in the U.S.? A new study, 'The Geography of Happiness,' analyzed 10 million tweets to map people's feelings. Lewis Michell, lead author of the study, joins digits.
fields.title: Where Are the Happiest Tweeters?

fields.description: Researchers analyzed ten million tweets to map happiness in the United States. Napa is happy. The Rust Belt is sad.
fields.author: Melody Kramer
fields.title: The Saddest Tweeters Live in Texas

fields.description: How can we measure happiness? Words used in tweets may hold the answer, according to a team of researchers who monitored Twitter to determine the happiest and saddest cities in the United States.
fields.author: Jessica Hartogs
fields.title: Tweets may show way to saddest city in the U.S.

fields.description: If you’re happy and you know it … send a Tweet? Researchers say that our word choices in social media reveal our emotions, and now they’ve used Twitter to map the country’s happiness.
fields.author: Sheila M. Eldred
fields.title: Twitter Used to Map Happiness

fields.description: Researchers at the University of Vermont are measuring the happiness of society by looking at the language used on Twitter. The verdict? Overall happiness--at least among Twitter users--has declined over the last three years.
fields.author: Michael Jourdan
fields.title: Measuring Happiness Tweet by Tweet

fields.description: University of Vermont mathematicians analyze billions of words in literature, music, and even Twitter, and find that happiness is a constant.
fields.author: Hans Villarica
fields.title: Study of the Day: English Is an Overwhelmingly Positive Language

fields.description: L'étude de la langue n'est pas qu'affaire de littéraires. Elle peut aussi intéresser mathématiciens et physiciens dès lors qu'il s'agit d'en dévoiler, par une approche statistique, le génie secret, les vertus cachées mais mesurables. C'est ce que vient d'essayer une équipe américaine de l'université du Vermont en voulant répondre à la question suivante : les langages sont-ils neutres sur le plan émotionnel ou bien contiennent-ils un biais affectif, positif ou négatif ? En clair, la langue a-t-elle une tendance naturelle, quel que soit le sujet évoqué, à l'optimisme ou au pessimisme ? De quelle manière le communicant qui se cache derrière tout Homo narrativus structure-t-il le contenu émotionnel de son récit (qu'il décrive une réalité ou une fiction) ou de ses dialogues, de sa prose ou de ses vers ?
fields.author: Pierre Barthélémy
fields.title: L'anglais, une langue optimiste?

fields.description: Today show excerpt on happiness of cities and states.
fields.author: Al Roker
fields.title: Happiest Cities on Twitter

fields.description: According to Twitter, it's the happiest city in the US! According to Amy, it's the drunkest.
fields.author: Ellen Degeneres
fields.title: Amy Drinks in Napa

fields.description: Rhode Show on State happiness rankings.
fields.author: Rhode Island TV News
fields.title: Rhode Island Morning TV

fields.description: Scientific figures and graphs are uncelebrated and utilitarian, a means to an end, unnoticed by graphics gurus and information designers -- but some stand out. They're the scientific world's folk art.
fields.author: Brandon Keim
fields.title: The Design of Science: 10 Great Research Graphics

fields.description: C'est tout Net ! Les nouvelles technologies contribuent-elles à notre bonheur ? Une étude du Chartered Institute for IT (BCS), parue en mai 2010, a établi un lien direct entre accès à Internet et bien-être.
fields.author: Par Marlène Duretz
fields.title: Pics de bonheur

fields.description: For millions of users, Twitter has become the place to communicate every thought that pops into their head - and it turns out they are not very happy ones.
fields.author: LOUISE BOYLE
fields.title: Is Twitter making us depressed? Analysis of tweets reveals 63m users are becoming more unhappy

fields.description: Well, this is depressing: A team of scientists from the University of Vermont appears to have proven via the judicious use of Twitter that people have been gradually growing more and more unhappy over the last three years.
fields.author: Graeme McMillan
fields.title: Science Proves Twitter Really Has Become More Sad Since 2009

fields.description: A team of mathematicians from the University of Vermont analyzed 4.6 billion Twitter messages over 33 months.
fields.author: Tim Johnson
fields.title: Tweets show global happiness has dropped

fields.description: The data could also be explained away by the fact that Twitter has grown explosively over the last two years -- perhaps early adopters are by nature more optimistic, and as Twitter has grown, the average happiness of its users has approached the mean.
fields.author: Matt Rosoff
fields.title: Happiness Is On The Decline, Says Twitter Study

fields.description: Based on tweets from 63 million users around the world, researchers find that global happiness is down.
fields.author: MEG HANDLEY
fields.title: Twitter: World Is Getting More Miserable

fields.description: Tweets can be seen as a reflection of an individual's mood of the moment.
fields.author: Tim Johnson
fields.title: Study finds Twitter reflects Americans' mood is gloomy

fields.description: Social scientists are turning to online retail giant Amazon.com to cheaply recruit people around the world for research studies.
fields.author: John Bohannon
fields.title: Social Science for Pennies

fields.description: Depending on your perspective, Twitter is a great way to promote a product, keep up with far-flung friends and colleagues, connect with others who share your passion for Korean boy bands, or maybe even start a revolution. The 5-year-old social media Web site now claims that more than 100 million users post 230 million “tweets” (text messages up to 140 characters long) every day. In that torrent of data, some social scientists see an unprecedented opportunity to study human communication and social networks.
fields.author: Greg Miller
fields.title: Social Scientists Wade Into the Tweet Stream

fields.description: At the beginning of this year, Isabel Kloumann and a group of mathematicians at the University of Vermont published a paper on positivity in the English language. They took just over 10,000 of the most frequent English words from a variety of sources (Twitter, Google Books, The New York Times, and music lyrics) and had people rate them on a 9 point scale from least happy to most happy, collecting 50 independent ratings per word. In the resulting dataset, available here, "laughter" comes in at number 1 in perceived happiness, and "terrorist" comes last.
fields.author: Arika Okrent
fields.title: 25 of the Happiest Words in English

fields.description: The authors of this study caution that it's still not clear from their data whether happy people just tend to find each other and cluster for that reason, and the negative likewise, or whether happiness spreads like a virus. However previous research has supported the contagion theory.
fields.author: Dr Raj Persaud
fields.title: New Research Reveals the Latest Secret to Happiness and Low Mood - How You Use Twitter

fields.description: I have an article in The Atlantic Cities about whether or not our opinions of cities fit all the statistics and rankings that we are constantly exposed to.
fields.author: Samuel Arbesman
fields.title: The Sentiments of Cities

fields.description: Scientists from the University of Vermont have undertaken an in-depth, extremely thorough examination of the emotions of the Twitterverse, and...
fields.author: Jen Doll
fields.title: Happiness Is on the Decline, at Least According to What We Tweet

fields.description: Social networking is a big deal, and not just for smart phone-addicted teens and reconnecting with long-lost friends. Twitter has grown into an incredibly useful way to disseminate information, and many reputable institutions, including PLoS and PLoS ONE, use it to share news and updates with thousands of people across the world.
fields.author: Rachel Bernstein
fields.title: Tweet for the sake of science

fields.description: Twitter users may be less happy than they used to be, say University of Vermont scientists.
fields.author: Cari Nierenberg
fields.title: Happiness Declining Among Twitter Users

fields.description: From what celebrities are doing at any given minute to the little things that irk ordinary people, there''s a lot to learn from Twitter. Researchers at the University of Vermont used the social media service to learn about people''s happiness and, through an analysis of billions of words used in millions of tweets, determined that societal happiness is on the decline. Over a period of three years, scientists gathered 46 billion words found in tweets by 63 million users around the world and, with the help of a web site, determined the "happiness" of the 10,000 most common words in...
fields.author: Kim Carollo
fields.title: Is Happiness Declining?  Twitter Analysis Says It Is

fields.description: It's been a bummer of a year--and now we've got the science to show it. Happiness levels are on the decline, according to a University of Vermont study that tracked the tone of billions of tweets sent over nearly three years.
fields.author: Bianca Bosker
fields.title: Happiness Is Dropping, Twitter Study Shows

fields.description: A massive language study, spanning Google Books, Twitter, popular songs lyrics and The New York Times, has found that English tends to look on the bright side of things. Positive words outnumber the negative.
fields.author: Brandon Keim
fields.title: Happy Words Trump Negativity in the English Language

fields.description: Trying to divine the mood of a group of people is hard and requires trust in their answers, but new methods of charting song lyrics or Twitter feeds sidesteps those issues.
fields.author: Michael Haederle
fields.title: Song Lyrics, Twitter Help Chart Public Mood

fields.description: Statisticians at the University of Vermont analyzed song lyrics, blogs and speeches to try to determine the national state of well-being.
fields.author: Benedict Carey
fields.title: Finding Clues to National Well-Being in Songs and Blogs

fields.description: Day in, day out, bloggers pour their feelings onto the Web. Now researchers are mining those outpourings to track society's mood swings.
fields.author: N/A
fields.title: Random Samples

fields.description: To be sure, gauging emotional and physical health has become an attractive area of research as indicators of a country's standing have expanded beyond the objectively economic to include more subjective measures of well-being.  Since 1972, Bhutan has measured national progress in terms of its Gross National Happiness, a mix of material, cultural and spiritual indicators.  Measuring the country's mood is usually done through surveys, but in their most recent study, Peter Sheridan Dodds and Christopher M. Danforth, mathematics professors at the University of Vermont, argue that traditional measurements of well-being can be
fields.author: Alejandro Martínez-Cabrera
fields.title: Web offering more gauges about happiness

fields.description: With nearly 200 million Twitter users who tweet around 65 million times each day, it was almost a given that scientists would start analyzing tweets to measure our happiness level and how its trending over time. In a depressing bit of news, University of Vermont researchers found that we're trending downward in our mood -- or at least in the positive language we use to express ourselves in tweets. But is the science valid?
fields.author: Deborah Kotz
fields.title: Is Twitter a valid tool for measuring happiness?

fields.description: Researchers find Wednesday really is full of woe
fields.author: Paul Gallagher
fields.title: Happy Mondays revealed by Tweeters and bloggers

fields.description: Lexicon: Hedonometer
fields.author: Department
fields.title: Lexicon: Hedonometer

fields.description: The Boomtown Rats were wrong - we do like Mondays. The first day back at work after the weekend was always assumed to be the day we are most miserable, but it is the second happiest day of the week.
fields.author: Paul Gallagher
fields.title: Yes, we love Mondays - our tweets say so

fields.description: Two scientists from Vermont have created a device that measures happiness by analyzing blog and Twitter posts, MSNBC reported.
fields.author: ALEXANDRA HAZLETT
fields.title: Scientists analyze Twitter, blogs, to learn how happy people are

fields.description: Miércoles es el peor día de la semana según análisis de mensajes de Twitter | SOCIEDAD
fields.author: GERARDO DE LA MAZA
fields.title: Miercoles es el peor dia de la semana segun analisis de mensajes de Twitter

fields.description: A method of measuring happiness based on blogs and Twitter has helped researchers highlight the happiest days in recent US history. The software created by Dr Peter Dodds and Dr Chris Danforth of the University of Vermont, collects sentences from blogs and 'tweets', zeroing in on the happiest and saddest days of the last few years.
fields.author: Eric Bland
fields.title: 'Happiness meter' analyses blogs, tweets

fields.description: N/A
fields.author: Belinda Goldsmith
fields.title: Jackson's death was blogosphere's saddest day: study

fields.description: Two Vermont statisticians are analyzing Twitter
fields.author: JENNA WORTHAM
fields.title: Using Twitter as a Collective Mood Ring

fields.description: Blogging about your crummy day? Writing a song about unrequited love? Your words may help researchers monitor society's mood swings.
fields.author: Michael Torrice
fields.title: How Happy Is the Internet?

fields.description: An online happiness gauge that searches blogs and tweets for mood-indicative words
fields.author: Ben Schott
fields.title: Hedonometer - Schott's Vocab

fields.description: Evaluating the happiness of an entire society is tricky–after all, the traditional survey-based method of collecting data doesn’t work for such a huge population. But now scientists say they have come up with a way to quantify the well-being of a society: by analyzing song lyrics and blog posts for emotionally charged words, according to a study published in the Journal of Happiness Studies. Among their findings, researchers determined that bloggers in their 50s and 60s are most content, and that popular music has become increasingly less happy since the 1960s.
fields.author: Allison Bond
fields.title: Pop Music and Blogs as Indicators of Gross National Happiness

fields.description: N/A
fields.author: Akash Goel
fields.title: How do we find life's benchmark?

fields.description: Two scientists are mining a vast amount of data, including 2.3 million blogs and English-language Tweets, to measure the happiness of America
fields.author: Charlie Burton
fields.title: Taking the pulse of Twitter

fields.description: It's a strange fact about social scientists that hardly any of them, in recent years, have paid any analytic attention to language, which is the main medium of human social interaction.  At schools of "communication", you'll generally find that neither the curriculum nor the faculty's research publications feature much if any analysis of speech and language. In other disciplines — sociology, social psychology, economics, history — you'll find even less of it. (The main systematic exception, Linguistic Anthropology, deserves a separate discussion — but the conclusion of such a discussion, I believe, would note a steep decline in empirical linguistic analysis. And of course I'm leaving out sociolinguistics, which is healthy enough but largely alienated from the rest of the social sciences.)
fields.author: Mark Liberman
fields.title: Linguistic analysis in social science

fields.description: How can we track how happy we are? Just look at blogs and song lyrics, two professors say.
fields.author: Marc Beja
fields.title: Think You're Happy? Song Lyrics May Have the Answer

fields.description: The mood of cyberspace has been probed by researchers who have found that Election Day, Nov. 4, 2008, was the happiest day in the past four years among 2.3 million bloggers, while the day Michael Jackson died was one of their unhappiest.
fields.author: Lynne Peeples
fields.title: Measuring emotion in cyberspace: Jackson's death a sad day; Obama's election a very happy one : )

fields.description: “If it bleeds, it leads,” goes the cynical saying with television and newspaper editors. In other words, most news is bad news and the worst news gets the big story on the front page.
fields.author: Joshua E. Brown
fields.title: Study: We May Be Less Happy, But Our Language Isn't

fields.description: The gross domestic product of the United States — that oft-cited measure of economic health — has been ticking upward for the last two years.
fields.author: Joshua E. Brown
fields.title: Study: Happiness Down

fields.description: On a recent rainy Thursday night, a couple hundred people gather after hours at the ECHO Lake Aquarium and Science Center to listen to a University of Vermont assistant professor of math and statistics talk about happiness — or, more specifically, using Twitter and other online communications as a barometer of happiness.
fields.author: Tyler Machado
fields.title: If You're Happy and You Know It, Tweet

fields.description: In a dizzying display of data mining, Chris Danforth ’01 invents a way to measure human happiness in real time.
fields.author: Wilson Ring
fields.title: Are We Happy Yet?

fields.description: In 1881, the optimistic Irish economist Francis Edgeworth imagined a strange device called a "hedonimeter" that would be capable of "continually registering the height of pleasure experienced by an individual." In other words, a happiness sensor.
fields.author: Joshua E. Brown
fields.title: If You're Happy, Then We Know It: Research Measures Mood

fields.description: A stock market-style "happiness index" that measures the mood of the world has been launched by US scientists, charting the mood of the planet on a graph that rises or falls, based on tweets.
fields.title: Hedonometer Happiness Index To Chart Moods Around The World

fields.description: University of Vermont professors create public website to track global happiness based on tweets
fields.author: Tim Johnson
fields.title: How happy are we? Hedonometer goes public

fields.description: University of Vermont and MITRE researchers have developed a way to monitor happiness in real time on a global scale using tweets
fields.author: Katy Edgington
fields.title: 'Hedonometer' measures global happiness via tweets

fields.description: The Hedonometer, which measures happiness based on Twitter posts, found April 15, 2013, was the saddest day in five years.
fields.author: Michelle McGuinness
fields.title: Boston Marathon bombing saddest day in 5 years on Twitter

fields.description: The Boston Marathon bombings caused the most pronounced wave of sadness across the Internet that the creators of Hedonometer had tracked in their five years of measuring online happiness.
fields.author: Damon Poeter
fields.title: Researchers: Boston Bombings Make the Internet Especially Sad

fields.description: Using the data scanned from Twitter mainly, scientists of UVM are calculating the levels of happiness across the globe. What forms the basis of the same is words used by the people on regular basis on CNN transcripts, Google data and The New York Times stories other than Twitter.
fields.author: Pauline Beart
fields.title: Scientists at UVM Calculate Global Happiness Levels using Hedonometer

fields.description: The day of the Boston Marathon bombing was the saddest for the United States in the last five years, a team of scientists says.
fields.title: Hedonometer calculates daily happiness, Boston Marathon unhappiest day

fields.description: The Hedonometer, which measures the world's daily happiness level primarily through words used on Twitter, is now be accessible to the public and provides daily updates 24 hours about the general mood on Earth.
fields.author: Jeffrey Kopman
fields.title: How Are You Feeling Today? The Hedonometer May Have the Answer

fields.description: Hedonometer is a new web platform that crunches Twitter data to measure levels of happiness across the English-speaking world
fields.author: Antonio Pasolini
fields.title: Hedonometer reads tweets to gauge social happiness

fields.description: Researchers in the US have revealed that the “hedonometer” or happiness sensor is a tool that is, for all intents and purposes a happiness sensor. The project went live at www.hedonometer.com on Tuesday.
fields.author: Bernadine Racoma
fields.title: Happiness Sensor Measures Mood via Tweets

fields.description: Is it possible to measure people’s levels of happiness based on the online data they produce? The team behind Hedonometer thinks so. Conceived by Peter Dodds and Chris Danforth at the University of Vermont’s Computational Story Lab, the software powering the platform, which recently went live, not only measures human happiness but does it in real time, too.
fields.author: Larra Morris
fields.title: Hedonometer reads tweets to gauge social happiness

fields.description: The death of Michael Jackson, the Japanese Tsunami in 2011, and the 2012 school shooting in Newtown, Conn. - the dates of these events are registered as some of the saddest days on Twitter since 2008, according to a new study led by the Computational Story Lab at the University of Vermont Complex...
fields.author: Daniel Bean
fields.title: Twitter Study Measures Day to Day Happiness of Last 5 Years

fields.description: What was the happiest day in America last year? Which are the saddest cities and 'hoods? The Hedonometer pools social messages to map our state of mind.
fields.author: Kate Rix
fields.title: How Happy Are We? Ask the Hedonometer.

fields.description: A recent study, conducted by researchers at the University of Vermont, once again looked into the question of where happy people live. Previous studies on the geography of personality, discussed in earlier GeoCurrents posts, were interview-based attempts to assess permanent personality traits (which may even be encoded genetically). This recent study looks at the state of happiness, temporary as it may be for any given person.
fields.author: Asya Pereltsvaig
fields.title: The Geography of Happiness—According to Twitter

fields.description: According to recent research measuring happiness on Twitter, Napa, California, is the happiest city in the nation while Beaumont, Texas is the saddest.
fields.author: Jane Susskind
fields.title: Mapping Happiness on Twitter: Where Does Your State Rank?

fields.description: Spend a little time in an airport and you’ll quickly be able to tell the travelers setting out on a trip from those returning: Departing...
fields.author: Dana McMahan
fields.title: Do well-needed vacations actually bum us out?

fields.description: You’ve heard of the Dow Jones, but have you heard of the Dow Jones Index of Happiness? Well, don’t beat yourself up about it, it’s new. Peter Dodds and Chris Danforth and their team in the Computational Story Lab at the University of Vermont Complex Systems Center partnered with the technology of Brian Tivnan, Matt McMahon and their team from the MITRE Corporation in order to produce an instrument that can measure happiness, called, simply, a Hedonometer.
fields.author: Anne Jamison
fields.title: A Fascinating Map Of Where the Happiest People Live

fields.description: Which way to happy? Geographically speaking, it's the route to Hawaii, Maine or one of the clusters of blissful cities in California and Colorado.
fields.author: Katy Hall
fields.title: The Happiest States In America In One Map

fields.description: A group of researchers from the University of Vermont have recently published a paper that ranks U.S. states and cities by the happiness of their tweets. Louisiana and Hawaii were at opposite ends of the scale.
fields.author: Daily Mail Reporter
fields.title: Twitter updates used to rank happiest and saddest US states

fields.description: After parsing the results from a recent University of Vermont study of geotagged tweets, the Huffington Post has compiled a map showing just how happy — or unhappy — Americans are according to the state they live in.
fields.author: George Dvorsky
fields.title: The Happiest Places in America

fields.description: WHY NOT NO. 1? What happens when you put a bunch of math geeks in a room with rows of computers? They come up with studies, the latest “proving” that Santa Barbara is only the 38th “happy” city in the U.S.
fields.author: Barney Brantingham
fields.title: Sweet Tweet Balance Sheet

fields.description: You may not be that bothered about the idea of living in a smart city but I bet you'd love to live in one that was happy.
fields.author: Jane Wakefield
fields.title: Tomorrow's cities: How big data is changing the world

fields.description: Last Monday, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) released a video of the past 10 years of weather in the Americas. The Geostationary Operational Environmental ...
fields.author: Evelyn Lamb
fields.title: The Most Breathtaking Video of the Weather You’ll Watch This Week

fields.description: Analysing mobile phone and Internet data can provide rapid information for decision-makers, says a UN initiative.
fields.author: Jan Piotrowski
fields.title: UN initiative mines big data to direct development
University of Vermont Researchers Hunt Down Hidden Network Nodes with the help of Eureka
